Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2015 10:55AM kittysister wrote: I decided to delete my posts. My problems with the rads could possibly cause newbies not to consider them. I wouldn't want to be responsible for that. I will be available for a private conversation if interested.  :)

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2015 10:00AM kittysister wrote: I remember those first in shock feelings. The first thing I thought of when I woke up in the mornings and the last thought before I went to sleep. It's easy to freak out, which I did at times. I agree on taking deep breaths. There is much to read and learn on these boards .. and there are so many of them .. hang in there .. there are many kind ladies here who are very knowledgable.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and feeling out of control demarie Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2015 12:12AM kittysister wrote: I am 66 and still looking for a place to land on these boards. So far, I've been all over the place. I feel worse for the younger ones who are fighting this disease than I do for myself, even though I've griped a lot and am still trying to come to terms with it. Anyway, I feel like I've led a full life so far, so consider myself lucky. I do still feel kind of like I'm living on the edge sometimes and could fall off at any time. Thank goodness for Medicare, because I had no idea going into this how expensive everything would be. I also got a supplement when I hit 65 and that has taken up the slack of what Medicare did not pay. I am sure glad I did. I guess every cloud does have a silver lining.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2015 07:23AM kittysister wrote: Nance- I was diagnosed at 65. I can relate to all the aching (especially my back). Nerves and stress can really do a number on your body! You're not going crazy. You just feel that way because of all you are going through and your mind is overloaded. I remember I even had a hard time even keeping up with all the appointments and phone calls. Keep posting and best of luck to you!
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with IDC, age 61. Nance1953 Nance1953

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2015 05:19PM kittysister wrote: I have psoriasis and what my rheumy DX'ed me with psoriatic arthritis in 2004. At the time, I had very good insurance that paid for Enbrel, which you all probably know is really expensive. I don't take it anymore. It gave me a racing heart and the nurse said to stop immediately. Now I wonder if there could be a connection to lowering the immune system and BC. Anyway, since the BC diagnose, I have noticed the psoriasis is getting a little worse. For me, it has always gotten worse with stress.
Posts.Title: How many with BC and autoimmune diseases like LUPUS, RA, ? badboob67 wintersocks

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2015 08:28PM kittysister wrote: All of my doctors have told me they don't know WHAT causes it. Different theories, I suppose. What I never did understand is how "health nuts" (sorry if that offends anybody- not my intention) get BC in spite of their good diets and exercise. Yet, so many who eat junk food and never exercise don't get it. Sorry, I haven't read this whole thread, but wanted to reply. No rhyme or reason to anything related to this horrible disease. I suspected stress and estrogen use in my case. But who knows and I can't afford to blame myself.
Posts.Title: Trying to find a common cause. Please help! sunny8 msphil
